clusters.title: Seoul promises to help hundreds of Korean workers arrested in US in Ice raid
clusters.neutral_headline: South Korea Reacts to Arrests at Hyundai Plant in Georgia

items.title: Seoul promises to help hundreds of Korean workers arrested in US in Ice raid
items.standfirst: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. Continue reading...
items.content: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. Continue reading...

items.title: Immigration Raid on Hyundai-LG Plant in Georgia Rattles South Korea
items.standfirst: A Hyundai plant in Ellabell, Ga., in March. On Thursday, U.S. law enforcement officers arrested hundreds of South Korean nationals at a neighboring construction site owned by Hyundai and LG.
items.content: A Hyundai plant in Ellabell, Ga., in March. On Thursday, U.S. law enforcement officers arrested hundreds of South Korean nationals at a neighboring construction site owned by Hyundai and LG.

items.title: How the Immigration Raid at Hyundai’s Factory Complex Unfolded
items.standfirst: About 475 people were detained, including hundreds of South Korean nationals who worked at the Georgia plant President Trump had hailed earlier this year.
items.content: About 475 people were detained, including hundreds of South Korean nationals who worked at the Georgia plant President Trump had hailed earlier this year.

items.title: US immigration agents arrest hundreds at Hyundai plant, mostly Koreans
items.standfirst: Hundreds of workers at a Hyundai Motor car battery facility under construction in Georgia were detained in a raid by U.S. authorities on Thursday, stopping work on a plant that is one of the Korean automaker's major investments in the U.S. President Donald Trump's administration has been escalating a crackdown on immigrants, disrupting businesses around the country, even as the White House has encouraged more inflows from foreign investors. Story by Peter O'Brien.
items.content: Hundreds of workers at a Hyundai Motor car battery facility under construction in Georgia were detained in a raid by U.S. authorities on Thursday, stopping work on a plant that is one of the Korean automaker's major investments in the U.S. President Donald Trump's administration has been escalating a crackdown on immigrants, disrupting businesses around the country, even as the White House has encouraged more inflows from foreign investors. Story by Peter O'Brien.

items.content: South Korea foreign affairs minister said he felt a "great sense of responsibility" over the arrest of more than 300 South Koreans.

items.title: 475 people detained in raid by ICE, other agencies at Hyundai site in Georgia

items.content: The operation targeted one of Georgia's largest and most high-profile manufacturing sites, where Hyundai makes electric vehicles and is building an EV battery plant.

items.content: Officers detained 475 people during an immigration raid on a Hyundai factory for electric vehicles in Georgia.

items.content: The Fortune 500 company confirmed the presence of law enforcement at the LG Energy Solution and Hyundai battery joint venture construction site in Ellabell.

ai_summary: Hundreds of South Korean workers were arrested at a Hyundai battery factory construction site in Georgia.
South Korea's president ordered "all-out efforts" in response to the arrests by US Immigration.
The South Korean foreign minister expressed a "great sense of responsibility" over the arrests.
US law enforcement detained approximately 475 people, including many South Korean nationals.
The arrests occurred at a construction site owned by Hyundai and LG near a Hyundai plant.

clusters.title: Trump executive order aims to rename the Department of Defense as the Department of War

items.title: Trump executive order aims to rename the Department of Defense as the Department of War
Palantir CEO Alex Karp Once Pushed For 'Department Of Offense' — Now Trump Rebrands Pentagon To 'War' Office As PLTR Touts America's AI Edge
items.standfirst: On Friday, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to rebrand the Pentagon as the "Department of War," echoing calls made last year by Palantir Technologies Inc. (NASDAQ:PLTR) CEO Alex Karp for a more offensive U.S. military posture as artificial intelligence reshapes global power. Trump…
items.content: On Friday, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to rebrand the Pentagon as the "Department of War," echoing calls made last year by Palantir Technologies Inc. (NASDAQ:PLTR) CEO Alex Karp for a more offensive U.S. military posture as artificial intelligence reshapes global power. Trump…

items.title: Trump signs executive order rebranding Pentagon as 'Department of War'
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Friday signed an executive order to rename the Department of Defense as the "Department of War", reverting to a title it held until after World War II. The switch was a signal that the department was "a force to be reckoned with", said Trump after months of complaining that the original name was "woke".
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Friday signed an executive order to rename the Department of Defense as the "Department of War", reverting to a title it held until after World War II. The switch was a signal that the department was "a force to be reckoned with", said Trump after months of complaining that the original name was "woke".

items.title: Trump signs Dept. of War order, announces 2026 G20 will be at Doral
items.standfirst: President Trump on Friday signed an executive order to begin the process of renaming the Department of Defense to the Department of War.
items.content: President Trump on Friday signed an executive order to begin the process of renaming the Department of Defense to the Department of War.

items.title: Behind Trump's order for Department of War name change
items.standfirst: President Trump signed his 200th executive order, seeking to rename the Department of Defense to the Department of War. The move restores the name the agency last held in the 1940s. Charlie D'Agata has more.
items.content: President Trump signed his 200th executive order, seeking to rename the Department of Defense to the Department of War. The move restores the name the agency last held in the 1940s. Charlie D'Agata has more.

items.title: Why the Department of War name is making a comeback
items.standfirst: President Trump began the process of renaming the Department of Defense to the Department of War. It's been more than 75 years since that name was used. CBS News' Aaron Navarro has more details.
items.content: President Trump began the process of renaming the Department of Defense to the Department of War. It's been more than 75 years since that name was used. CBS News' Aaron Navarro has more details.

items.title: Defense Department Scrambles to Pretend It’s Called the War Department
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said the so-called Department of War branding is to counter the “woke” Department of Defense name.
items.content: President Donald Trump said the so-called Department of War branding is to counter the “woke” Department of Defense name.

items.title: Trump rebrands Department of Defense as Department of War
items.standfirst: The US president has sought to refocus the department on "warfighting" and a "warrior ethos".
items.content: The US president has sought to refocus the department on "warfighting" and a "warrior ethos".

items.title: Trump signs executive order renaming Defense to Department of War
items.standfirst: President Trump singed an executive order Friday directing the Department of Defense to use the name Department of War as a "secondary title" — restoring a name it last held in the late 1940s.
items.content: President Trump singed an executive order Friday directing the Department of Defense to use the name Department of War as a "secondary title" — restoring a name it last held in the late 1940s.

items.title: Trump changes the Department of Defense’s name to ‘Department of War’
items.standfirst: Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth says the name change signals a more offensive approach for the US military under Trump.
items.content: Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth says the name change signals a more offensive approach for the US military under Trump.

ai_summary: President Trump signed an executive order to rename the Department of Defense to the Department of War.
The name change reverts to a title the agency held until after World War II.
The move was Trump's 200th executive order during his presidency.
The rebranding echoes calls from Palantir CEO Alex Karp for a more offensive military.
Trump stated the name change was to counter the "woke" Department of Defense name.

items.content: The Israeli military has ordered residents of Gaza City to evacuate to a designated “humanitarian zone” as its forces intensify a major offensive.

items.content: Any remaining residents in Gaza's largest city should leave for a designated area in the south, Israel's military has warned.

items.content: The Israeli military on Saturday urged Palestinians in Gaza City, the enclave's largest urban area, to leave for what it called a "humanitarian zone" further south, ahead of a planned offensive.

The Israeli military has established control over 40% of Gaza City.
The evacuation order comes as Israel intensifies its major offensive in Gaza.
The Israeli army urged Palestinians to use the "opportunity" to leave Gaza City.

clusters.title: Google hit with massive fine from European Union in ad-tech antitrust case
clusters.neutral_headline: EU Fines Google, Trump Threatens Retaliatory Tariffs

items.title: Google hit with massive fine from European Union in ad-tech antitrust case
items.standfirst: European Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a 2.95 billion euro ($3.5 billion) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, but the bloc's latest move to crack down on Big Tech companies drew outrage from President Donald Trump. Story by Laurent Berstecher.
items.content: European Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a 2.95 billion euro ($3.5 billion) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, but the bloc's latest move to crack down on Big Tech companies drew outrage from President Donald Trump. Story by Laurent Berstecher.

items.title: Trump threatens new tariffs over EU's $3.5 billion antitrust fine against Google
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Friday lashed out against the European Union’s $3.47 billion antitrust fine against Google as “unfair” and threatened retaliatory tariffs if the bloc does not reverse the penalty. Trump's rebuke came a day after he hosted tech leaders, including Google’s top executives, at a White House dinner.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Friday lashed out against the European Union’s $3.47 billion antitrust fine against Google as “unfair” and threatened retaliatory tariffs if the bloc does not reverse the penalty. Trump's rebuke came a day after he hosted tech leaders, including Google’s top executives, at a White House dinner.

items.title: Trump threatens retaliatory tariffs after EU hits Google with €2.95bn fine
items.standfirst: US president criticises ‘very unfair’ measures a day after he hosts tech chiefs at the White House
items.content: US president criticises ‘very unfair’ measures a day after he hosts tech chiefs at the White House

items.title: EU fines Google nearly €3bn for ‘abusing’ dominant position in ad tech
items.standfirst: Regulators ordered the tech giant to end ‘self-preferencing practices’ in advertising services but declined to force saleEuropean Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a €2.95bn ($3.5bn) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, marking the fourth such antitrust penalty for the company as well as a retreat from previous threats to break up the tech giant.The European Commission, the 27-nation bloc’s executive branch and top antitrust enforcer, also ordered the US company to end its “self-preferencing practices” and take steps to stop “conflicts of interest” along the advertising technology supply chain. Continue reading...
items.content: Regulators ordered the tech giant to end ‘self-preferencing practices’ in advertising services but declined to force saleEuropean Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a €2.95bn ($3.5bn) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, marking the fourth such antitrust penalty for the company as well as a retreat from previous threats to break up the tech giant.The European Commission, the 27-nation bloc’s executive branch and top antitrust enforcer, also ordered the US company to end its “self-preferencing practices” and take steps to stop “conflicts of interest” along the advertising technology supply chain. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump Threatens Trade Actions After EU Fines Google Over Ads
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump threatened a probe on the European Union that could prompt fresh tariffs, in response to the bloc’s fining of Alphabet Inc.’s Google over findings the company exploited its advantage over rivals.
items.content: US President Donald Trump threatened a probe on the European Union that could prompt fresh tariffs, in response to the bloc’s fining of Alphabet Inc.’s Google over findings the company exploited its advantage over rivals.

ai_summary: The European Union fined Google 2.95 billion euros for breaching competition rules.
The EU found Google favored its own digital advertising services.
President Trump criticized the fine as "unfair" and threatened retaliatory tariffs.
Trump's rebuke followed a White House dinner with tech leaders, including Google executives.
The EU ordered Google to end "self-preferencing practices" in advertising services.

items.title: Anthropic settles with authors in first-of-its-kind AI copyright infringement lawsuit
items.standfirst: A U.S. district court is scheduled to consider whether to approve the settlement next week, in a case that marked the first substantive decision on how fair use applies to generative AI systems.
items.content: A U.S. district court is scheduled to consider whether to approve the settlement next week, in a case that marked the first substantive decision on how fair use applies to generative AI systems.(Image credit: Riccardo Milani/Hans Lucas/AFP via Getty Images)

items.title: Anthropic Agrees to Pay Authors at Least $1.5 Billion in AI Copyright Settlement
items.standfirst: Anthropic will pay at least $3,000 for each copyrighted work that it pirated. The company downloaded unauthorized copies of books in early efforts to gather training data for its AI tools.
items.content: Anthropic will pay at least $3,000 for each copyrighted work that it pirated. The company downloaded unauthorized copies of books in early efforts to gather training data for its AI tools.

items.title: Anthropic Reaches $1.5 Billion Author Copyright Settlement
items.standfirst: Anthropic PBC will pay at least $1.5 billion plus interest to resolve an authors’ copyright lawsuit over the AI company’s downloading of millions of pirated books, one of the largest settlements over artificial intelligence and intellectual property to date.
items.content: Anthropic PBC will pay at least $1.5 billion plus interest to resolve an authors’ copyright lawsuit over the AI company’s downloading of millions of pirated books, one of the largest settlements over artificial intelligence and intellectual property to date.

ai_summary: Apple faces a class-action lawsuit alleging illegal use of copyrighted books for AI training.
Authors Grady Hendrix and Jennifer Roberson filed the lawsuit in California.
Anthropic agreed to pay $1.5 billion to settle an AI copyright infringement lawsuit.
The Anthropic settlement is one of the largest AI copyright settlements to date.
A U.S. district court will consider approving the Anthropic settlement next week.

clusters.title: Judge blocks Trump administration's ending of protections for Venezuelans and Haitians
clusters.neutral_headline: Judge Blocks Trump Administration's TPS Termination

items.title: Judge blocks Trump administration's ending of protections for Venezuelans and Haitians
items.standfirst: A federal judge on Friday blocked the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections for more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela who live in the United States.
items.content: A federal judge on Friday blocked the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections for more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela who live in the United States.(Image credit: Gerald Herbert)

items.title: Judge rules ending protections for Venezuelan and Haitian migrants is unlawful
items.standfirst: The decision is in response to the Trump administration's efforts to end temporary protected status (TPS).
items.content: The decision is in response to the Trump administration's efforts to end temporary protected status (TPS).

items.title: Judge blocks Trump from ending TPS for Venezuelans and Haitians
items.standfirst: A federal judge in California ruled that the Trump administration's attempt to end the Temporary Protected Status program for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelan and Haitian migrants was unlawful. Camilo Montoya-Galvez explains.
items.content: A federal judge in California ruled that the Trump administration's attempt to end the Temporary Protected Status program for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelan and Haitian migrants was unlawful. Camilo Montoya-Galvez explains.

items.title: Judge rules against Trump's attempt to end protections for Venezuelans, Haitians
items.standfirst: Judge Edward Chen ruled against the Trump administration in a challenge to its effort to end the Temporary Protected Status program for roughly 1 million Venezuelan and Haitian migrants.
items.content: Judge Edward Chen ruled against the Trump administration in a challenge to its effort to end the Temporary Protected Status program for roughly 1 million Venezuelan and Haitian migrants.

items.title: Judge blocks ending of legal protections for 1m Venezuelans and Haitians in US
items.standfirst: Homeland security had tried to end temporary protected status granted by the Biden administrationA federal judge on Friday ruled against the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections that have granted more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela the right to live and work in the United States.The ruling by US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means that 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire on 10 September have status to stay and work in the United States. Continue reading...
items.content: Homeland security had tried to end temporary protected status granted by the Biden administrationA federal judge on Friday ruled against the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections that have granted more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela the right to live and work in the United States.The ruling by US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means that 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire on 10 September have status to stay and work in the United States. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A federal judge blocked the Trump administration from ending TPS for Venezuelans and Haitians.
The ruling protects over 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela.
The judge ruled against the Trump administration's attempt to end TPS.
The ruling was in response to the Trump administration's efforts to end TPS.
The ruling means 600,000 Venezuelans can stay and work in the US.

clusters.title: As Trump invokes Alien Enemies Act for deportations, is admin pursuing regime change in Venezuela?
clusters.neutral_headline: US Deploys Fighter Jets Amidst Tensions with Venezuela

items.title: As Trump invokes Alien Enemies Act for deportations, is admin pursuing regime change in Venezuela?
items.standfirst: The United States is sending ten F-35 fighter jets to Puerto Rico as part of President Donald Trump's vow to crack down on drug cartels in the Caribbean. The deployment of the aircraft to the US territory comes amid growing tensions over Washington's build-up in the region, where the Pentagon claims two Venezuelan military planes buzzed a US ship. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, FRANCE 24's Gavin Lee welcomes David A. Smilde, Charles A. and Leo M. Favrot Professor of Human Relations & Department of Sociology Chair at Tulane University.
items.content: The United States is sending ten F-35 fighter jets to Puerto Rico as part of President Donald Trump's vow to crack down on drug cartels in the Caribbean. The deployment of the aircraft to the US territory comes amid growing tensions over Washington's build-up in the region, where the Pentagon claims two Venezuelan military planes buzzed a US ship. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, FRANCE 24's Gavin Lee welcomes David A. Smilde, Charles A. and Leo M. Favrot Professor of Human Relations & Department of Sociology Chair at Tulane University.

items.title: US weighs strikes on cartels in Venezuela, F-35 warplanes deploy: Reports
items.standfirst: Ten F-35 stealth fighter jets reported to be joining US naval operation against Latin American drug cartels.
items.content: Ten F-35 stealth fighter jets reported to be joining US naval operation against Latin American drug cartels.

items.title: Trump sends 10 stealth fighter planes to Puerto Rico amid war on Caribbean drug cartels
items.standfirst: Move comes after US accuses Venezuela of buzzing warship and a deadly US missile strike in Caribbean SeaDonald Trump is sending 10 F-35 fighter jets to Puerto Rico to bolster US military operations against drug cartels in the Caribbean region, it was reported on Friday.If follows a deadly US missile strike on Tuesday on a boat in the Caribbean Sea that the Trump administration insisted was carrying 11 Venezuelan drug traffickers, and comments by the secretary of state, Marco Rubio, on Wednesday that such attacks “will happen again”. items.title: Japanese prince comes of age, delaying the male-only succession debate
items.standfirst: Japan’s Prince Hisahito, the nephew of Emperor Naruhito, received a traditional black silk and lacquer crown to mark his 19th birthday Saturday. His birth in 2006 marked an end to a brief debate on the country's male-only succession rule since the emperor's only child is his daughter, Princess Aiko.

items.title: UK's Starmer overhauls his cabinet after deputy PM resigns amid tax scandal
items.standfirst: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Friday undertook the first major reshuffle of his cabinet since coming to power in July 2024, after deputy premier Angela Rayner resigned following a tax scandal. Her departure comes as Starmer's Labour government has been struggling to achieve its main goal of firing up Britain's economy.
items.content: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Friday undertook the first major reshuffle of his cabinet since coming to power in July 2024, after deputy premier Angela Rayner resigned following a tax scandal. Her departure comes as Starmer's Labour government has been struggling to achieve its main goal of firing up Britain's economy.

items.title: Tax scandal sinks U.K. deputy leader in huge blow to embattled PM Keir Starmer
items.standfirst: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer's Labour Party deputy Angela Rayner resigned Friday after admitting underpaying property taxes.
items.content: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer's Labour Party deputy Angela Rayner resigned Friday after admitting underpaying property taxes.

ai_summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer reshuffled his cabinet.
The reshuffle followed Deputy PM Angela Rayner's resignation.
Rayner resigned due to a tax scandal.
Starmer's Labour government is struggling to boost the economy.
Rayner admitted underpaying property taxes.

items.standfirst: The Italian fashion designer and billionaire brand owner Giorgio Armani has died at the age of 91.

items.title: Giorgio Armani, iconic Italian fashion designer, dies at 91

items.content: The legendary Italian fashion designer Giorgio Armani has died, the company he founded said Thursday.
